ca.ualberta.cmput301f13t13.storyhoard.controllers

Class StoryController

  • java.lang.Object
    • ca.ualberta.cmput301f13t13.storyhoard.controllers.StoryController

  • public class StoryController
extends java.lang.Object
    Role: Responsible for manipulating the story model. It keeps a reference to the current story model as a field and updates that whenever the user makes changes. Every time the user creates a new story or saves his changes to one, the changes are pushed to the database, and whenever the story is published, changes are saved to the server.

    Design Pattern: This class is a singleton, so only one instance of it will ever exist. use getInstance() to retrieve that instance, not the constructor.
    Author:
    Stephanie Gil

    • Method Detail

      • getInstance

        public static StoryController getInstance(Context context)
        Returns an instance of a StoryController. The same instance is always returned since it is a singleton. This is the method every other class should be using to access the StoryController. Note that this method must also be called statically.

        Example call:
        StoryController control = StoryController.getInstance(someActivity.this);
        Parameters:
        context - Could be an activity or application context.

      • setCurrStoryIncomplete

        public void setCurrStoryIncomplete(Story aStory)
        Sets its story to whatever story is passed in. Using this method also means that the story you are passing in is not "complete". This means that its chapters are empty, only the actual story data like title and author is contained. Therefore, this method will retrieve all the chapters (as well as any choices and media belonging to those chapters) and will set these chapters as the story's chapters so it is now a "complete" story.

        Example call:
        Story myStory = new Story("Title", "author", "desc", "123bfdg6");

        Assume that myStory has chapters belonging to it in stored in the database.

        StoryController control = StoryController.getInstance(someActivity.this);
        control.setCurrStoryIncomplete(myStory);

        The story field in StoryController is now has any chapters it had stored in the database.
        Parameters:
        aStory - A story object assumed to be missing its chapters.

      • setCurrStoryComplete

        public void setCurrStoryComplete(Story aStory)
        Sets its story to whatever story is passed in. Using this method also means that the story you are passing in is "complete". This means that it has all of its chapters within in, including any choices and media belonging to those chapters. There is no need to retrieve them from the database

        Example call:
        Story myStory = new Story("Title", "author", "desc", "123bfdg6");

        Chapter chap = new Chapter(myStory.getId(), "The guy on second floor of comp sci has a really scary and annoying laughter while I try to finish documenting this never ending project");
        StoryController control = StoryController.getInstance(someActivity.this);
        control.setCurrStoryComplete(myStory);

        Parameters:
        aStory - A story object assumed to have all of its chapters ready.

      • getCurrStory

        public Story getCurrStory()
        Returns a reference to the current story model.

        Example Call:
        StoryController control = StoryController.getInstance(someActivity.this);
        Story myStory = control.getCurrStory();

      • editFirstChapterId

        public void editFirstChapterId(java.util.UUID id)
        Edits the story model's first chapter id. No view is allowed to do this directly, so they use this method.

        Example Call:
        Story myStory = new Story("Title", "author", "desc", "123bfdg6");
        StoryController control = StoryController.getInstance(someActivity.this);
        control.setCurrStoryComplete(myStory);

        UUID newChapId = UUID.randomUUID();
        control.editFirstChapter(newChapId);
        Parameters:
        id - Id of the chapter you want to set as the story's first chapter. Note that it must be a UUID.

      • editTitle

        public void editTitle(java.lang.String title)
        Edits the story model's first chapter id. No view is allowed to do this directly, so they use this method.

        Example Call:
        Story myStory = new Story("Title", "author", "desc", "123bfdg6");
        StoryController control = StoryController.getInstance(someActivity.this);
        control.setCurrStoryComplete(myStory);

        UUID newChapId = UUID.randomUUID();
        control.editTitle("I have the best titles");
        Parameters:
        title - Title (a string) you want to set as the story's title.

      • editAuthor

        public void editAuthor(java.lang.String author)
        Edits the story model's title. No view is allowed to do this directly, so they use this method.

        Example Call:
        Story myStory = new Story("Title", "author", "desc", "123bfdg6");
        StoryController control = StoryController.getInstance(someActivity.this);
        control.setCurrStoryComplete(myStory);
        UUID newChapId = UUID.randomUUID();
        control.editAuthor("Voldemort");
        Parameters:
        author - Author (a string) you want to set as the story's title.

      • editDescription

        public void editDescription(java.lang.String desc)
        Edits the story model's description. No view is allowed to do this directly, so they use this method.

        Example Call:
        Story myStory = new Story("Title", "author", "desc", "123bfdg6");
        StoryController control = StoryController.getInstance(someActivity.this);
        control.setCurrStoryComplete(myStory);
        UUID newChapId = UUID.randomUUID();
        control.editDescription("yay annoying laugh guy in second floor comp sci has stopped laughing. I think the guy trying to finish 304 really appreciates that.");
        Parameters:
        desc - Description (a string) you want to set as the story's description.

      • addChapter

        public void addChapter(Chapter chapter)
        Adds a chapter onto the story object. If the story has no chapters when the new chapter is added, the firstChapterId will also be set for the story.

        Example Call:
        Story myStory = new Story("Title", "author", "desc", "123bfdg6");
        StoryController control = StoryController.getInstance(someActivity.this);
        control.setCurrStoryComplete(myStory);
        Chapter chap = new Chapter(myStory.getId(), "blah blah");
        control.addChapter(chap);
        Parameters:
        chapter - Chapter object you want to add to the story

      • updateChapter

        public void updateChapter(Chapter chapter)
        Updates a chapter of the story model. Does so by finding the chapter, deleting it, and inserting the new version of it.

        Example call:
        Example Call:
        Story myStory = new Story("Title", "author", "desc", "123bfdg6");
        StoryController control = StoryController.getInstance(someActivity.this);
        control.setCurrStoryComplete(myStory);
        Chapter chap = new Chapter(myStory.getId(), "blah blah");
        control.addChapter(chap);
        chap.setText("nennwweww");
        control.updateChapter(chap);
        Parameters:
        chapter - Chapter containing the new data you want to replace the old chapter with.

      • pushChangesToServer

        public java.lang.Boolean pushChangesToServer()
        Any changes to the story model will now be pushed to the server. This is called any time the user publishes or republishes a story. If the update was successful, the method returns true. Else, if there were problems, the method returns false.

        Example Call:
        Story myStory = new Story("Title", "author", "desc", "123bfdg6");
        StoryController control = StoryController.getInstance(someActivity.this);
        control.setCurrStoryComplete(myStory);

        control.editTitle("new title");
        control.pushChangesToServer();

      • pushChangesToDb

        public void pushChangesToDb()
        Any changes to the story model will now be pushed to the database so the database information is consistent.

        Example Call:
        Story myStory = new Story("Title", "author", "desc", "123bfdg6");
        StoryController control = StoryController.getInstance(someActivity.this);
        control.setCurrStoryComplete(myStory);

        control.editTitle("new title");
        control.pushChangesToServer();
